body:
You must first meet with a mediator to check if mediation is right for you. This is called a pre-mediation meeting.

If you or the other parent wants to go to [court]({app:urls:route:going_to_court}) this initial meeting is called a [Mediation Information and Assessment Meeting (MIAM)](https://www.familymediationcouncil.org.uk/family-mediation/assessment-meeting-miam/).

The parent applying to court is legally required to show they’ve considered mediation by attending a MIAM, unless [they’re exempt](https://www.familymediationcouncil.org.uk/family-mediation/assessment-meeting-miam/miams-exemptions/). The other parent is also expected to attend.

At either meeting the mediator will explain:

- how mediation works
- the benefits
- whether it’s right for you
- the likely costs
- if you’re eligible for free mediation through [legal aid](https://checklegalaid.service.gov.uk/)

Only authorised mediators can carry out a MIAM. Check with the mediator before you book.
cost: Average cost of MIAM per person
cost_description: Estimated fees may vary depending on your location and the experience of the mediator. Some mediators offer reductions if you’re unemployed or on a low income. It may also be cheaper if you attend together.
heading: Book initial meeting with mediator
